title: 104_hr4162
content: The Act titled "Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996" allows certain individuals to continue participating in defined benefit plans under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. The Act titled "Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996" allows qualified beneficiaries to elect continued participation in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event, ensuring the accrual of benefits without a break in service. A participant can maintain nonforfeitable accrued benefits and accrual of benefits by continuing participation with the employer after a qualifying event, as per the Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to maintain nonforfeitable accrued benefits by continuing participation with the employer, excluding earnings and forfeitures for liability determination in multiemployer plans. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to maintain nonforfeitable accrued benefits by continuing participation with the employer, excluding earnings and forfeitures for liability determination in multiemployer plans. Liability allocation in multiemployer plans is determined by the plan sponsor or the last employer employing the person before the qualifying event. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to maintain nonforfeitable accrued benefits by continuing participation with the employer. The period of participation extends from the date of the qualifying event until the participant reaches normal retirement age or the employer ceases to provide any defined benefit plan. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to maintain accrued benefits by continuing participation with the employer until normal retirement age or the employer stops providing a defined benefit plan. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to maintain accrued benefits by continuing participation with the employer until normal retirement age or the employer stops providing a defined benefit plan. Qualified beneficiaries electing continued participation are liable for funding any obligation of the plan to provide benefits, including employer contributions and mandatory employee contributions. The plan shall allocate applicable contributions to qualified beneficiaries in the same manner as for beneficiaries without a qualifying event, including employer and employee contributions. Benefit accruals from voluntary employee contributions are also provided for. The plan allocates contributions to beneficiaries similarly, regardless of qualifying events. Benefit accruals from voluntary employee contributions are only available if they were prior to the event. Participants are deemed to have received compensation as if they continued in service. During continued participation, the participant is deemed to have received compensation as if they continued in service at a rate of 1,000 hours of work per 12-month period. Contributions by the qualified beneficiary are limited to 102 percent of the applicable contribution for the period. During continued participation, the qualified beneficiary's contributions are limited to 102 percent of the applicable contribution for the period and may be made in monthly installments. The plan cannot require payment before 45 days after the initial election for continued participation. The election period begins no later than the date of the initial election. During continued participation, the qualified beneficiary's contributions are limited to 102 percent of the applicable contribution for the period and may be made in monthly installments. The election period begins not later than the date benefits would cease, lasting at least 90 days. During continued participation, qualified beneficiaries can elect to continue their benefits for at least 90 days. The election also covers other beneficiaries affected by the qualifying event. Certain defined benefit plans with fewer than 20 employees are exempt from this provision. The exception for defined benefit plans with fewer than 20 employees exempts them from certain provisions. Definitions for applicable contributions and qualified beneficiaries are provided. Beneficiaries receive benefits equal to the actuarial value of benefit accruals from the period of continued participation. A qualified beneficiary is any beneficiary under the plan before the qualifying event, including the participant. A qualifying event is any event within seven years of the participant reaching normal retirement age. The term 'qualifying event' refers to specific events within seven years of the participant reaching normal retirement age that would result in the cessation of benefit accruals for a qualified beneficiary, such as termination or reduction of employment hours or the death of the participant. SEC. 3. EFFECTIVE DATES. This Act applies to plan years starting on or after July 1, 1996, with a special rule for defined benefit plans under collective bargaining agreements ratified before the Act's enactment date, exempting them until the termination of agreements or January 1, 2000.
